title: Psalms Chapter 69 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 69 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 69 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 69.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalm 69 according to Psalms 69:1?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:1 states that this is a Psalm of David.

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:2, what has the psalmist sunk into?
questions.correctAnswer: Deep mire
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:2 says, 'I sink in deep mire, where there is no standing.'

questions.question: In Psalms 69:3, what physical condition does the psalmist describe from crying?
questions.correctAnswer: Throat is dried
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:3 says, 'my throat is dried' from crying.

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:4, the psalmist had restored what?
options: That which he took not away
questions.correctAnswer: That which he took not away
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:4 mentions, 'then I restored that which I took not away.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 69:5 says that God does not know the psalmist's sins.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:5 says 'O God, thou knowest my foolishness; and my sins are not hid from thee,' meaning God knows his sins.

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:7, what has covered the psalmist's face?
questions.correctAnswer: Shame
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:7 states, 'shame hath covered my face.'

questions.question: In Psalms 69:8, the psalmist says he is a stranger to whom?
options: His brethren and his mother's children
questions.correctAnswer: His brethren and his mother's children
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:8 says, 'I am become a stranger unto my brethren, and an alien unto my mother's children.'

questions.question: What did the psalmist make his garment according to Psalms 69:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Sackcloth
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:11 states, 'I made sackcloth also my garment.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:13, to whom is the psalmist's prayer directed?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:13 says, 'my prayer is unto thee, O LORD.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 69:20 mentions that the psalmist found many comforters.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:20 says the psalmist found none for comforters.

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:21, what did the psalmist receive to drink when he was thirsty?
questions.correctAnswer: Vinegar
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:21 states, 'in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 69:30: 'I will praise the name of God with a _____, and will magnify him with thanksgiving.'
questions.correctAnswer: song
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:30 says, 'I will praise the name of God with a song.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:33, whom does the LORD hear?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:33 states, 'For the LORD heareth the poor.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 69:35 says God will destroy the cities of Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:35 says God will save Zion and build the cities of Judah.

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:36, who will inherit the possession God has established?
questions.correctAnswer: The seed of his servants
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:36 says, 'The seed also of his servants shall inherit it.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 69 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 69 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is overwhelmed by trials and feels like sinking in deep troubles. Based on Psalms 69, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in such times?
options: God hears the poor and saves those in distress
Trials mean God has abandoned you
You must face troubles alone without prayer
Endure silently without seeking God’s help
questions.correctAnswer: God hears the poor and saves those in distress
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:1-2 describes sinking in deep waters, yet verse 33 assures that 'the LORD heareth the poor, and despiseth not his prisoners.' Verses 14-16 also show a plea for deliverance and God's lovingkindness, teaching us to trust God in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 69 teach about humility and repentance when facing sin and failure?
options: Confess sins openly to God because He knows your foolishness
Hide your sins and pretend to be perfect
Ignore your sins and continue as usual
questions.correctAnswer: Confess sins openly to God because He knows your foolishness
questions.explanation: Verse 5 says, 'O God, thou knowest my foolishness; and my sins are not hid from thee.' This teaches believers to be humble and repentant before God, acknowledging our faults honestly.

questions.question: A believer is feeling rejected by family because of their faith. Based on Psalms 69, what encouragement can you offer about enduring alienation for God's sake?
options: Being a stranger to family for God’s sake is part of faithful obedience
One should abandon faith to maintain family ties
Family rejection means God is displeased
Avoid fellowship with others to prevent rejection
questions.correctAnswer: Being a stranger to family for God’s sake is part of faithful obedience
questions.explanation: Verse 8 says, 'I am become a stranger unto my brethren, and an alien unto my mother's children,' showing that enduring rejection can be part of faithfulness to God. This encourages perseverance.

questions.question: What does Psalms 69 teach about the power of prayer during times of distress?
options: Prayer is a vital expression of trust and seeking God's mercy
God does not hear prayers in hard times
One should only pray when feeling happy
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is a vital expression of trust and seeking God's mercy
questions.explanation: Verses 13, 16 and 17 emphasize prayer: 'my prayer is unto thee... hear me,' and 'Hear me, O LORD; for thy lovingkindness is good.' This shows prayer as essential in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 69 illustrate the importance of spiritual disciplines like fasting and mourning in dealing with reproach?
options: Fasting and mourning express repentance and deepen dependence on God
These practices are useless and bring shame
They are only for show to impress others
Avoid fasting and mourning to maintain a cheerful appearance
questions.correctAnswer: Fasting and mourning express repentance and deepen dependence on God
questions.explanation: Verses 10 and 11 mention fasting and sackcloth as expressions of sorrow and repentance amid reproach, teaching believers to use spiritual disciplines sincerely.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with enemies who wrongfully persecute them. What does Psalms 69 teach about God’s justice in response to such persecution?
options: God will bring judgment upon the persecutors
Ignore the injustice and do nothing
questions.correctAnswer: God will bring judgment upon the persecutors
questions.explanation: Verses 22-28 describe God's indignation and judgment upon enemies who persecute the godly, showing divine justice will prevail.

questions.question: What biblical principle on praise and thanksgiving does Psalms 69 teach for those delivered by God?
options: Praise God with song and thanksgiving as a response to salvation
Only sacrifices please God, not thanksgiving
Praise should be silent and hidden
questions.correctAnswer: Praise God with song and thanksgiving as a response to salvation
questions.explanation: Verse 30 states, 'I will praise the name of God with a song, and will magnify him with thanksgiving,' highlighting praise as proper response after God's deliverance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 69 encourage believers to remain humble and content during hardships?
options: The humble shall see and be glad, and their hearts shall live
Pride will protect you from troubles
Hardships are a sign of God's rejection
questions.correctAnswer: The humble shall see and be glad, and their hearts shall live
questions.explanation: Verse 32 teaches that humility leads to gladness and life, encouraging believers to remain humble and content in trial.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 69, God despises those who are poor and imprisoned.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 33 states, 'the LORD heareth the poor, and despiseth not his prisoners,' showing God cares for the needy and imprisoned.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 69 teaches that faithful believers should expect to be reproached and bear shame for God's sake.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 6-9 speak about bearing reproach and shame because of faithfulness to God, indicating it is part of godly perseverance.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 69 says, 'They gave me also ___ for my meat; and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink.'
questions.correctAnswer: gall
questions.explanation: Verse 21 mentions 'They gave me also gall for my meat; and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink,' illustrating the bitterness endured by the psalmist.

questions.question: What does Psalms 69 teach about the integrity of restoring what we have not taken, even when wrongly accused?
options: Restore what you have not taken to maintain integrity despite accusations
Take what you want if accused unjustly
Ignore accusations and keep ill-gotten gains
Accept blame even if it is false
questions.correctAnswer: Restore what you have not taken to maintain integrity despite accusations
questions.explanation: Verse 4 says, 'then I restored that which I took not away,' highlighting the importance of honesty and integrity even when falsely accused.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by lack of comforters in suffering. What does Psalms 69 teach about turning to God in such loneliness?
options: God is near and hears those in trouble, even when human comfort is absent
Suffering means God has rejected you
Seek comfort only from people, not God
Loneliness is a sign of failure in faith
questions.correctAnswer: God is near and hears those in trouble, even when human comfort is absent
questions.explanation: Verse 20 expresses loneliness, but verses 16-17 encourage calling on God for help, affirming God's nearness in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 69 guide believers to respond to those who persecute God's servants?
options: Trust God to add iniquity to their iniquity and bring justice
Ignore persecution and pretend it does not exist
Seek to please persecutors to avoid conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to add iniquity to their iniquity and bring justice
questions.explanation: Verses 26-27 call on God to punish persecutors by adding to their sins and not allowing them into righteousness, teaching reliance on God's justice.

questions.question: What does Psalms 69 reveal about the blessings for those who love God's name and serve Him faithfully?
options: They will inherit and dwell in the possession God provides
They will be forgotten and punished
Serving God leads to worldly riches only
Faithful service means isolation from others
questions.correctAnswer: They will inherit and dwell in the possession God provides
questions.explanation: Verses 35-36 promise salvation for Zion and inheritance for God's servants who love His name, encouraging faithful service.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 69 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 69.

questions.question: In Psalms 69:1, the phrase 'waters are come in unto my soul' metaphorically represents what kind of experience?
questions.correctAnswer: Overwhelming distress and danger
questions.explanation: The metaphor of waters coming into the soul in Psalms 69:1 signifies an overwhelming flood of troubles and danger, not a physical or joyful event.

questions.question: What Hebrew word translated as 'zeal' in Psalms 69:9 carries a connotation of intense passion often linked to divine jealousy?
questions.correctAnswer: qinah
questions.explanation: In Psalms 69:9, 'zeal' corresponds to the Hebrew word 'qinah,' which carries the meaning of fervent passion, often associated with God's protective jealousy over His house.

questions.question: The imagery of 'gall for my meat' and 'vinegar to drink' in Psalms 69:21 foreshadows which New Testament event?
questions.correctAnswer: The crucifixion of Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:21's mention of gall and vinegar directly prefigures the New Testament account of Jesus being offered vinegar on the cross (Matthew 27:34).

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:4, what reason does David give for the hatred he experiences from his enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: Without a cause
questions.explanation: David states in Psalms 69:4 that those who hate him do so without cause, emphasizing the injustice of his persecution.

questions.question: How does the literary structure of Psalms 69 emphasize the contrast between the psalmist's suffering and hope in God?
options: Through parallelism contrasting distress and deliverance
Through a simple hymn of praise
questions.correctAnswer: Through parallelism contrasting distress and deliverance
questions.explanation: Psalms 69 employs Hebrew parallelism to juxtapose the psalmist’s affliction and his confident appeal for divine rescue, reflecting a common poetic structure.

questions.question: In Psalms 69:7-8, what social consequence does David describe as a result of bearing reproach for God's sake?
options: Becoming a stranger to his own family
questions.correctAnswer: Becoming a stranger to his own family
questions.explanation: David in Psalms 69:7-8 laments that his reproach for God's sake causes alienation even from close family members.

questions.question: What is the significance of David wearing sackcloth as mentioned in Psalms 69:11 in the ancient Near Eastern context?
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolized mourning and penitence
questions.explanation: Wearing sackcloth in Psalms 69:11 denotes mourning and repentance, a cultural practice in the ancient Near East signaling sorrow and humility.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 69:33, the LORD despises his prisoners and ignores their pleas.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:33 states that the LORD hears the poor and does not despise his prisoners, indicating divine compassion rather than neglect.

questions.question: In Psalms 69:13, the psalmist’s prayer is described as being in an 'acceptable time.' What theological theme does this reflect?
options: God’s readiness to hear sincere prayer
questions.correctAnswer: God’s readiness to hear sincere prayer
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:13 emphasizes that God hears prayers in due time, reflecting the theme of divine readiness to respond to sincere petitions.

questions.question: Which literary device is predominantly used in Psalms 69:22-28 where the psalmist calls for judgment upon his enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: Imprecatory poetry
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:22-28 is a classic example of imprecatory poetry, where the psalmist invokes curses on his adversaries.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 69:30 states, 'I will praise the name of God with a song, and will ______ him with thanksgiving.'
questions.correctAnswer: magnify
questions.explanation: The verse Psalms 69:30 expresses praise through song and magnifying God with thanksgiving, indicating exaltation and gratitude.

questions.question: How does Psalms 69:35 connect with the broader biblical theme of restoration and hope for Israel?
options: God will save Zion and build the cities of Judah, symbolizing restoration
Israel will be permanently scattered without hope
The psalmist will become king over all nations
The temple will be destroyed forever
questions.correctAnswer: God will save Zion and build the cities of Judah, symbolizing restoration
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:35 affirms God’s promise to save Zion and rebuild Judah’s cities, reflecting the biblical motif of covenantal restoration.

questions.question: What cultural significance does 'they that sit in the gate' have in the context of Psalms 69:12?
options: They represent local authorities or community elders
questions.correctAnswer: They represent local authorities or community elders
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern culture, 'those who sit in the gate' were often elders or officials who judged and discussed matters publicly, as in Psalms 69:12.

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:16-17, what attributes of God does the psalmist appeal to in his plea for deliverance?
questions.correctAnswer: Lovingkindness and tender mercies
questions.explanation: The psalmist appeals to God’s lovingkindness and tender mercies in Psalms 69:16-17, emphasizing God’s compassionate nature in times of trouble.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 69:31 claims that offering praise to God is less pleasing than sacrificing bulls and oxen.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:31 states that praise and thanksgiving are more pleasing to the LORD than sacrifices of bulls and oxen, demonstrating the superiority of heartfelt worship.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 69 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 69 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:1, what metaphor does David use to describe his desperate condition?
options: The waters have come into my soul
I walk through a valley of shadows
I am trapped in a cage
questions.correctAnswer: The waters have come into my soul
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:1 uses the vivid metaphor of waters coming into the soul to express overwhelming distress. This imagery is consistent with other biblical uses such as in Isaiah 43:2 and Jonah 2:3 where waters represent danger and deliverance by God. Jesus also used water imagery to depict spiritual life in John 7:38.

questions.question: In Psalms 69:4, what reason does David give for being hated by his enemies?
options: They hate him without a cause
questions.correctAnswer: They hate him without a cause
questions.explanation: David explicitly states in Psalms 69:4 that his enemies hate him without cause, highlighting the innocence and undeserved suffering of the righteous which aligns with the suffering servant motif in Isaiah 53:3 and Jesus' experiences as noted in John 15:25. This also underlines the biblical theme of unjust persecution of the godly (1 Peter 2:20).

questions.question: What does David acknowledge about his own sin in Psalms 69:5?
options: God knows his foolishness and sins are not hidden
His sins are forgiven and forgotten
He does not recognize his sins
questions.correctAnswer: God knows his foolishness and sins are not hidden
questions.explanation: In Psalms 69:5, David confesses that God is fully aware of his foolishness and sins, which aligns with the biblical doctrine of God’s omniscience (Psalm 139:2-4). This confession of sinfulness is foundational to biblical repentance (1 John 1:9) and humility before God (Proverbs 3:5-6).

questions.question: What does Psalms 69:9 reveal about David's passion for God's house?
options: The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up
He is indifferent towards God's house
He seeks to build a new temple
He is angry with the priests
questions.correctAnswer: The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up
questions.explanation: This verse expresses David’s deep zeal for the honor of God's house, reflecting the biblical principle of righteous zeal as seen in John 2:17 where Jesus was zealous for the Father’s house. It also echoes Moses’ zeal for God’s glory (Exodus 32:19) and Paul’s passion for God’s kingdom (Romans 9:1-3).

questions.question: How does David describe his social alienation in Psalms 69:8?
options: I am become a stranger unto my brethren
I am honored among my people
I am surrounded by loyal friends
I dwell peacefully with my family
questions.correctAnswer: I am become a stranger unto my brethren
questions.explanation: David describes profound alienation from his kin in Psalms 69:8, portraying the loneliness and rejection that the righteous often face, which is consistent with the experience of the messianic sufferer in Isaiah 53:3 and Jesus’ alienation from His own (John 1:11). This highlights biblical themes of suffering and rejection for righteousness’ sake (Matthew 5:10).

questions.question: In Psalms 69:13, how does David characterize his prayer to God?
options: A prayer in an acceptable time
questions.correctAnswer: A prayer in an acceptable time
questions.explanation: David calls his prayer 'in an acceptable time' in Psalms 69:13, expressing trust that God hears prayers according to His perfect timing, which corresponds to biblical teachings on prayer (Ecclesiastes 3:1, Isaiah 55:6, and 1 Peter 3:12). It reflects faith in God's mercy and salvation as foundational to effective prayer (Hebrews 4:16).

questions.question: What plea does David make in Psalms 69:14 regarding his enemies?
options: Deliver me from them that hate me
Join my enemies and make peace
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver me from them that hate me
questions.explanation: David pleads for deliverance from his enemies in Psalms 69:14, illustrating the biblical theme of God as protector and deliverer (Psalm 34:17, Psalm 144:7). This request shows trust in God's justice and mercy, consistent with New Testament teachings on praying for persecutors (Matthew 5:44).

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:20, what emotional state does David reveal due to reproach and lack of comfort?
questions.correctAnswer: Broken heart and heaviness
questions.explanation: David expresses a broken heart and heaviness in Psalms 69:20 due to rejection and absence of comforters, reflecting the biblical reality of suffering and despair (Psalm 34:18, Isaiah 61:1). This aligns with Christ’s experiences of sorrow (Luke 22:44) and the biblical promise of God's comfort (2 Corinthians 1:3-4).

questions.question: What symbolic food and drink do David’s enemies give him in Psalms 69:21?
options: Gall for meat and vinegar for drink
questions.correctAnswer: Gall for meat and vinegar for drink
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:21 speaks of gall and vinegar given to David, symbolic of bitterness and mockery. This prophetic imagery is fulfilled in the New Testament where Jesus is offered vinegar on the cross (Matthew 27:34, John 19:29-30), emphasizing the messianic suffering theme and rejection by men (Isaiah 53:3).

questions.question: How does David request God to respond to his enemies in Psalms 69:24?
options: Pour out thine indignation and wrath upon them
Bless them with peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: Pour out thine indignation and wrath upon them
questions.explanation: David asks for God's indignation and wrath on his enemies in Psalms 69:24, reflecting the biblical doctrine of divine justice (Romans 12:19, Psalm 7:11). This acknowledges God's righteous judgment against evil and protection of His people, consistent with scriptures such as Nahum 1:2 and Revelation 19:15.

questions.question: What ultimate destiny does David pronounce upon his enemies in Psalms 69:28?
options: Be blotted out of the book of the living
questions.correctAnswer: Be blotted out of the book of the living
questions.explanation: In Psalms 69:28, David pronounces a curse that his enemies be blotted out of the book of the living, a biblical metaphor for exclusion from God's eternal life (Exodus 32:32, Revelation 20:15). This reflects the eschatological judgment theme where the wicked are separated from the righteous (Matthew 25:46).

questions.question: What attitude does David express about his own condition in Psalms 69:29?
questions.correctAnswer: I am poor and sorrowful
questions.explanation: David humbly acknowledges his poverty and sorrow in Psalms 69:29, echoing the biblical theme of the poor in spirit whom God lifts up (Psalm 34:6, Matthew 5:3). This humility is foundational for salvation and divine blessing (James 4:6).

questions.question: According to Psalms 69:30, how does David vow to respond to God's salvation?
options: By praising God's name with a song and thanksgiving
By offering sacrifices of bulls and oxen
By seeking revenge on his enemies
questions.correctAnswer: By praising God's name with a song and thanksgiving
questions.explanation: David commits to praising God with song and thanksgiving in Psalms 69:30, highlighting worship as the proper response to salvation (Psalm 100:4, Hebrews 13:15). This reflects the biblical principle that thanksgiving and praise honor God more than ritual sacrifices (Psalm 50:8-9, Hosea 6:6).

questions.question: What does Psalms 69:33 say about God's attitude toward the poor and prisoners?
options: The LORD heareth the poor and despiseth not his prisoners
God ignores the poor and prisoners
The LORD favors only the wealthy
God punishes the poor and prisoners
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD heareth the poor and despiseth not his prisoners
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:33 emphasizes God's compassion for the marginalized, showing He hears and values the poor and prisoners. This truth aligns with numerous scriptures such as Isaiah 61:1, Luke 4:18, and James 2:5, showing God’s preferential care for the oppressed and the promise of justice.

questions.question: What future hope is expressed in Psalms 69:35 concerning Zion and Judah?
options: God will save Zion and build the cities of Judah
Zion and Judah will be destroyed forever
Zion and Judah will be forgotten
Zion and Judah will become pagan lands
questions.correctAnswer: God will save Zion and build the cities of Judah
questions.explanation: Psalms 69:35 expresses the eschatological hope that God will save Zion and rebuild Judah, consistent with prophetic promises of restoration (Isaiah 61:4, Jeremiah 30:18). This reflects God's faithfulness to His covenant and the ultimate salvation and dwelling of His people (Revelation 21:2-3).
